question: Please describe in no more than 200 words the following:
llm_answer: The PeriTox test (UKN5) is an in vitro assay that evaluates compound-induced impairment on neurite outgrowth using human iPSC‐derived immature dorsal root ganglia neurons. In this assay, previously differentiated peripheral neurons are thawed and seeded onto Matrigel-coated plates in a defined medium containing N2-S and KSR supplemented with pathway inhibitors. One hour after seeding, test compounds are added and, following a 24-hour exposure, cells are stained with H-33342 and calcein-AM for simultaneous assessment of neurite area and cell viability via high-content imaging. The neurite area serves as an indirect measure of neuronal interconnectivity, while viable cell counts confirm toxicant specificity. Positive and negative controls (narciclasine reducing neurite area, DMSO as solvent control) ensure assay robustness. The method is designed to predict both developmental neurotoxicity and adverse effects on mature peripheral neurons, helping determine hazards such as peripheral neuropathies. Its quantitative endpoint evaluation and medium-to-high throughput capacity make it a valuable tool for neurotoxicity screening and hazard assessment. (Source: PeriToxtest(UKN5).pdf)

question: Provide information on machine settings, analytical standards, data processing and normalization procedures. For imaging endpoints: provide detailed algorithm. This information should also be covered in an SOP, preferably in DB-ALM format (see link in 6.6).
gtruth_answer: Quantification of neurite outgrowth An automated microplate reading microscope (Array-ScanII HCS Reader, Cellomics, PA) equipped with a Hamamatsu ORCA-ER camera (resolution 1024 x 1024; run at 2 x 2 binning) was used for image acquisition. Ten fields per well were imaged. Images were recorded in 2 channels using a 20x objective and excitation/emission wavelengths of 365 ± 50/535 ± 45 to detect H-33342 in channel 1 and 474 ± 40/535 ± 45 to detect calcein in channel 2. In both channels, a fixed exposure time and an intensity histogram-derived threshold were used for object identification. Neurite pixels were identified using the following image analysis algorithm: nuclei were identified as objects in channel 1 according to their size, area, shape, and intensity which were predefined on untreated cells using a machine-based learning algorithm, and manual selection of nuclei to be classified as intact. The nuclear outlines were expanded by 3.2 µm in each direction, to define a virtual cell soma area (VCSA) based on the following procedure: The average width of the cytoplasm ring (distance nucleus - cell membrane) of LUHMES cells was experimentally determined to be 2.3 µm. Size irregularities were not always due to growing neurites, as determined by combined F-actin/tubulin beta-III staining. To avoid scoring of false positive neurite areas, the exclusion ring (VCSA) was made bigger than the average cell size. Then, we used two control compounds (U0126 and bisindolylmaleimid I) to vary the expanded outlines from 0.6 to 4 µm. We found 3.2 µm to be optimal both to detect neurite growth over time and to identify reduced neurite growth with high sensitivity. All calcein-positive pixels of the field (beyond a given intensity threshold) were defined as viable cellular structures (VCSs). The threshold was dynamically determined for each field after flat field and background correction and intensity normalization to 512 gray values and was set to 12% of the maximal brightness (channel 63 of 512). The VCS defines the sum of all somata and neurites without their assignment to individual cells. In an automatic calculation, the VCSAs, defined in the H- 33342 channel, were used as filter in the calcein channel and subtracted from the VCS. The remaining pixels (VCS - VCSA) in the calcein channel were defined as neurite area. Quantification of individual viable cells by imaging For a quantitative assessment of viable cells, the same images used to assess neurite area were analyzed using another image analysis algorithm: nuclei were identified in channel 1 as objects according to their size, area, shape, and intensity. Nuclei of apoptotic cells with increased fluorescence were excluded. A VCSA was defined around each nucleus by expanding it by 0.3 µm into each direction. Calcein-AM staining, labeling live cells, was detected in channel 2. The algorithm quantified the calcein intensity in the VCSA areas. Cells having an average calcein signal intensity in the VCSAs below a predefined threshold were classified by the program as “not viable”. Valid nuclei with a positive calcein signal in their cognate VCSA were counted as viable cells. A positive calcein signal was based on measurements of the average intensity (normal cells: 1300 ± 115, threshold: < 50) and the total integrated intensity (normal cells: 186,000 ± 23,600, threshold < 1000) of cells.

1. Machine Settings and Imaging Parameters  
 • The images are acquired using a Cellomics Array Scan VTI HCS Reader equipped with a Hamamatsu ORCA-ER camera (1024 × 1024 resolution, 2 × 2 binning) using a 20× objective.  
 • Two fluorescent channels are used:  
  – Channel 1 (for Hoechst H‑33342 staining): excitation at 365 ± 50 nm and emission at 535 ± 45 nm.  
  – Channel 2 (for calcein‑AM staining): excitation at 474 ± 40 nm and emission at 535 ± 45 nm.  
 • Exposure times are set manually and an intensity histogram‑derived threshold is used for object identification.

2. Analytical Standards and Controls  
 • Positive control compound narciclasine (50 nM final concentration) is used to validate assay sensitivity; its criteria require a neurite area ≤75% of DMSO-treated controls while viability remains ≥90%.  
 • The standard solvent control is 0.1% DMSO, which also sets the baseline for normalization (e.g. control neurite area must be ≥150,000).  
 • Endpoint‑specific controls for neurite growth inhibition (e.g. vincristine, colchicine, cytochalasin D) and enhancement (e.g. Y‑27632) further ensure analytical consistency.

3. Detailed Algorithm for Imaging Endpoints  
 A. For Neurite Outgrowth Quantification:  
  • The Hoechst channel (channel 1) is used to identify nuclei based on predefined criteria (size, shape, intensity) optimized on untreated cells using a machine‐learning algorithm with manual selection of “intact” nuclei.  
  • Once nuclei are identified, each nuclear outline is expanded by 3.2 µm in all directions to create a Virtual Cell Soma Area (VCSA). This expansion, determined empirically using control compounds, is critical to exclude the cell body from the measurement of neurite outgrowth.  
  • In channel 2, all calcein‑positive pixels (after dynamic thresholding, set at 12% of the maximal brightness normalized to 512 gray values) are defined as viable cellular structures (VCS).  
  • The neurite area is calculated by subtracting the VCSA (the area corresponding to the cell bodies) from the total calcein‑positive area (VCS).  
 B. For Viable Cell Quantification:  
  • Using images from channel 1, each nucleus is again identified as described, and a small VCSA is defined by expanding the nucleus outline by 0.3 µm.  
  • The calcein‑AM signal in the corresponding VCSA (channel 2) is measured for average intensity and total integrated intensity. Cells with average intensities below a preset threshold (e.g. normal cells typically average around 1300, with thresholds defined at <50 for non‑viable cells) and low total signals (normal cells around 186,000, with a threshold <1000) are classified as non‑viable.  
  • Only nuclei with a positive calcein signal are counted as viable.

4. Data Processing and Normalization  
 • Images are first analyzed locally on the Array Scan software, which automatically quantifies neurite area, total nuclei (cell count), and viable cell count.  
 • Processed data are then exported (copy‑pasted into Excel files) and further analyzed using programs such as GraphPad Prism. Nonlinear regression fits (4‑parameter log functions) are used to derive concentration–response curves.  
 • Normalization is performed relative to the vehicle control (0.1% DMSO): for instance, the acceptance criteria require that control wells show a minimum neurite area of 150,000.  
 • Intra‑ and inter‑experimental variations (baseline variations on neurite outgrowth and viability) are calculated as part of the quality control measures.

5. SOP Documentation

• Pipetting errors: Using multichannel pipettes demands careful, slow pipetting. Errors such as droplets not reaching the medium (if dispensed too high) and mis-pipetting can cause well-to-well variation.

The processing workflow starts at image acquisition and then moves through several clearly defined steps. First, images are captured using the Cellomics Array Scan VTI HCS Reader with fixed exposure times in two channels. In the calcein channel (for neurite structures and viable cell staining), a flat‐field and background correction is applied to each field. Here, the intensity is normalized (to 512 gray values) and a dynamic threshold is determined (set to 12% of the maximal brightness) so that all calcein-positive pixels may be identified. At the same time, a separate analysis of the Hoechst H‐33342 channel is performed to identify nuclei, and the nuclear outlines are expanded (by 3.2 µm) to create a virtual cell soma area (VCSA). Subtracting the VCSA from the overall viable cellular structure (VCS) area in the calcein channel provides an estimate of the neurite area.

Next, the software calculates numerical endpoints from each well, namely the neurite area, total nuclei count and the count of viable (double positive) cells. These raw quantitative data from all technical replicates are then copy‑pasted into an Excel file.

(i) In the dichotomized prediction model the assay defines a “hit” as a decrease in neurite area that occurs without overt cytotoxicity. In practice, the positive control (narciclasine at 50 nM) is used as reference, with toxic responses defined as neurite area ≤75% of the DMSO control while viability remains ≥90% of the DMSO control. This dichotomizes the outcome into clearly “toxic” (neurite area reduced beyond the threshold without viability compromise) or “non‑toxic” (no significant neurite reduction, or viability is affected) _(Source: PeriToxtest(UKN5).pdf sections “Endpoint-specific controls” and “Acceptance criteria for the test method”)_.

(ii) For outcomes that are pseudo‑dichotomized with an additional borderline category, the prediction model is based on quantitative measures using the ratio of the benchmark concentrations (BMC25) for viability (V) and neurite area (NA). A ratio BMC25(V)/BMC25(NA) ≥ 3 is considered indicative of a neurite‐specific effect. Compounds with values around this threshold are deemed “borderline” – that is, if the ratio is near 3 (taking into account experimental uncertainty, for instance when the viability endpoint fails to reach the BMC25, using the highest tested concentration instead). This borderline range was initially defined mathematically based on control compounds (unspecific toxicants showed an average ratio of 1.38 ± 0.39, and a noise band of 4×SD was calculated, leading to a threshold of roughly 3) _(Source: PeriToxtest(UKN5).pdf, “Prediction model” section)_.

(iii) For multi‑class or continuous outcomes, the endpoints (neurite area and cell viability) are quantified as continuous values and analyzed using non‐linear regression (4‑parameter log functions). The threshold is defined with a benchmark response of 25% (BMC25) rather than using EC50 values. The rationale is both mathematical and biological: mathematically, using the BMC25 makes the model more robust because many compounds do not induce a full 50% reduction in neurite outgrowth over the test concentration range; biologically, the thresholds (e.g. neurite area reduction and maintaining viability ≥90% of control) are based on known toxicological responses, as compounds that affect the cytoskeleton and neurite outgrowth without a concurrent drastic reduction in viability are considered selectively neurotoxic. This approach helps distinguish specific neurite effects from general cytotoxicity _(Source: PeriToxtest(UKN5).pdf, “Prediction model and toxicological application” section)_.

Rationale and limitations:  
• The threshold of a 3‑fold difference (or ratio ≥ 3) is set based on the observed average ratio of unspecific toxicants (1.38 ± 0.39) and the calculated noise band (approximately 4× the standard deviation), providing a mathematically robust and toxicologically meaningful cutoff.  
• The toxicological rationale is that a reduction in neurite area in the absence of significant cytotoxicity (viability remaining around 90% or above) likely reflects a specific interference with neurite outgrowth mechanisms.  
• Limitations include potential variability due to differences in cell differentiation, compound-related issues such as autofluorescence, technical handling limitations (e.g. pipetting inaccuracies, imaging inconsistencies), and the fact that the prediction model does not capture all aspects of in vivo neurotoxicity. Moreover, the model is based on a defined range of test concentrations and might not fully extrapolate beyond them.

In screening mode, a “hit” is defined as any compound that causes a significant change in neurite area (i.e. a reduction to ≤75% of the DMSO control) without concomitant loss of viability (maintained at ≥90% of control) – or, using the BMC25-based model, when the BMC25 ratio (Viability/Neurite Area) is ≥3. This hit definition is used to flag compounds for follow‑up evaluations and mechanistic testing _(Source: PeriToxtest(UKN5).pdf, “Prediction model” and “Endpoint-specific controls” sections)_.
